About me

I was trained as a theoretical chemist. Now I'm actively practicing statistical mechanics and machine learning to study biology. My ultimate goal is to provide a landscape perspective on biological processes, including biomolecular folding and assembly, genetic and epigenetic regulation.

Postdoc in Chemistry, MIT, 2017-now

PhD in Chemistry, Peking University, 2017

BSc in Chemistry and Mathematics, Peking University, 2012

Visting Student at Max Planck Institute for Polymer Research, 2016

chromatin structure and epigenetics

Why human has multiple cell types with the same DNA sequence? Because different cells have distinct epigenome. We aim to understand how such epigenetic information is established and maintained using statistical physics. One of our predictions that heterochromatin can spread through chromatin looping has been recently confirmed in experiment. The epigenome also affects the spatial organization of chromatin, which plays critical roles in genome function. Our analysis of single-cell super-resolution chromatin imaging data unraveled the phase separation mechanism caused by epigenome patterns. Importantly, we are able to quantify the energy landscape of chromatin folding using machine learning and statistical physics.

water and aqueous solutions

Water and aqueous solutions are important for life and are widespread in nature. Their properties can be best studied at the molecular level using molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. For instance, we combined ab-initio MD simulations, polarization-resolved femtosecond infrared pump-probe spectroscopy, and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy to learn how TMAO interact with urea in marine animals. We employed force-field MD simulations to explain the salt effects on protein structure and counterion effects on the ice nucleation on polyelectrolytes. These studies prompted us to propose a simple theory for the famous Hofmeister series.
